a global infrastructure model we publish a global infrastructure map and on that
map we show you several different important things we show you in the orange boxes we show you the locations

and we also show you the AWS edge locations with those red circles which indicate the locations of our content
distribution and our our dns service edge locations it's extremely important
for you to know that when you choose to store data process data in the cloud you
have complete choice and control of where that happens if for for reasons of
latency or legal reasons or just personal choice you need to keep your information in the US you have the
choice of multiple AWS regions in the US if for other reasons you say I need
to be close to my customers and my customers are in the Far East or if they're in Europe or they're in South America you can choose among those
regions and it is really important just to know that once you make the choice of that region that is where all of your
processing all of your storage will take place it's only with your explicit
command and consent that we would ever move information from one region to another as you can see from the map
there are currently eight separate locations for in the US including what's called the AWS gov cloud that's reserved
for government customers and applications we have a region in Portland another one in San Francisco
and then the the fourth one is located on the east coast of the US in Northern Virginia our newest region is located in
Brazil there's a region in Ireland and then both tokyo and singapore so that
this is our current map we actually added four of those regions just in the last year so you can you can trust that
we will continue to add additional regions to that map over time within
each of the regions we have a further subdivision that we call an availability zone or an AZ for short when you choose
to build your application we strongly recommend that you distribute your functionality across two or more
availability zones in an individual region each of the zones in a region is
equipped with its own physical security network connectivity power cooling and
control infrastructure the design model is that any local event that might
affect a single availability zone is going to be isolated from the other availability zones in the same region we
give you full control again like you have control of the region's you have control of the ability to launch your
your servers your ec2 instances in any of the availability zones within a
region we give you services such as automatic scaling and load balancing you also let you distribute functionality
across the zones in a region so we often
get asked about security and in the past I used to believe the this information for late in the presentation I found
that it's actually very helpful to cover it up front so that we we address the security questions that invariably arise and that
way you don't have to kind of keep those in mind for later so we we've really built AWS to make sure that we're
meeting enterprise level security standards we over the last years we've invested very heavily in a number of
certifications as you can see listed on the slide there from things like sock one type to formally known as SAS 70 ISO
27001 PCI DSS for a number of the services for government apps we have
things like FISMA moderate and HR and we have a number of customers building HIPAA applications in the cloud that
must process sensitive personal information we take strong precautions
with respect to the physical security in our in our data centers the data centers are all housed in very nondescript
facilities you will never ever see a blinking light on top of a blinking sign on top of an Amazon data center that
advertises what it is it's just a bland plain building physical access to the
data centers is very strictly controlled there's just a very few employees that are allowed in and out and those
employees have to pass through at least two levels of two-factor authentication to get access to a particular floor of a
data center all of the access to the particular areas of the data center is logged and periodically audited and all
these details if you need to know more about any of these particular things we do publish a security white paper available from our website and then at
the hardware/software networking level we're extremely methodical when it comes
to change management we have a very well-documented and controlled procedure when we roll out changes into the the
various systems that comprise AWS those are always done on a phased model they're always done on a part of an
availability zone at a time and then as we roll those out we carefully test
those and then roll those out across the remainder of the the network we have a
set of documented procedures for decommissioning storage including D Gaussian magnetic devices and then shredding them into tiny little bits of
metal and plastic there's a number of automated monitoring it and auditing facilities built into the system as well
again if you have any questions about these please feel free to enter those questions or i would also refer you to

storage so our different facilities are are designed for different types of backup and disaster recovery the first
one amazon s3 is designed to offer very highly durable blob storage so by highly
durable i mean we we've designed this to offer 11 nines of durability and that
means if you store ten thousand objects with us we expect to lose one object about every ten million years or so s
trees designed to be excellent for backup and archive because there's blob storage you're always storing entire
objects in s ray there's no concept of updating an s3 object you're always drawing the entire objects to us those objects in 10 range
in size from a single bite on up to five terabytes the other type of storage is
called elastic block storage or EBS for short and when you have these abs data
volumes you can create these in any size from one gigabyte up to one terabyte
these are persistent data volumes that you create and then attach to any of any amazon ec2 instance in a particular
availability zone there is redundancy behind the each elastic block store
volume and they do have a published reliability and durable durability figure for them when you have data
stored on an EBS volume we give you facilities we also encourage you to make snapshots of that data when you create
these ABS snapshots you can use then use those to recover the data volumes with just a single click in the AWS
management console the snapshot backups are actually stored in amazon s3 and give you the long-term durability and
also the abilities as i said to recreate these these volumes within a region so
an essential part of your of your your planning and you're thinking when you start to think about dr is to choose the
proper types of storage we just announced some new numbers yesterday for
amazon s3 and got a lot of really really great coverage of those numbers as you
can see from the the right-hand column on this chart at the end of the fourth quarter of 2011 we actually are
restoring 762 billion objects in amazon s3 we also process over 500,000 requests
per second for those objects now also keep in mind when you look at this that there's redundancy behind the scenes in
amazon s3 so these are actually customer objects and s3 behind the scenes is keeping multiple copies of these objects
and transparently recovering from any any issues that might arise so we talked

that with either one gigabit or 10 gigabit bandwidth and full details on

another option is brand new this is called the the storage gateway service and we put this together because we saw

with a virtual appliance of software appliance you install that on a host in

shots and use those snapshots to then create actual EBS disk values that the

to debt create this object called a VPC when you create it you assign it an IP
address range you then break that IP address range down into subnets just the
same kinds of things you would do if you were building your own corporate network from scratch you break it down into subnets you get to establish access
control rules you get to put virtual routers between the different subnets and you can even control the routing
tables that control how the traffic is able to transit from subnet to subnet
you can then create a VPN gateway from your data center across to your virtual
private cloud that you create so in effect what you've done you've created this virtual extension of your local

private cloud and then accessible your data center almost as if they were on your your local network this is a
wonderful way to take the the often limited resources that you have inside your your current network and then

you should know about when we talk about security is called the dedicated instance so with the dedicated instance
what you're able to do is you're able to launch an ec2 instance in with a special
designator on it that simply says I only want virtual instances from my own

when you decide to launch the virtual instances the ec2 instances you simply check one check box and say I'd like

well you would be creating this am I you'd put your operating system your applications your tools all of your

idea of with the pilot light model is we're going to be always sending our data update us keep keeping the

going to have a very very low recovery point objective low meaning that's it's a very very small amount of time and
we're then going to have just kind of a very moderate amount of processing

am is that we've carefully put together we launch your application server we launch our web server and weary target
